clinical_scenario: Evaluation of saline breast implants. Any age. Initial imaging.
comment: US cannot detect saline leakage. Intervention is purely on clinical grounds

clinical_scenario: Evaluation of cosmetic silicone breast implants Suspected implant rupture/complication.
comment: Refer for privately funded imaging/surgical review -DHB specialist review/imaging not routinely accepted

clinical_scenario: Evaluation of non-cosmetic, silicone breast implants. Suspected implant rupture/complication. Any age. Initial imaging prior to Surgical review.
comment: GP-referred US then refer for review by initial operating surgeon if abnormal/equivocal

clinical_scenario: Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
modality: US +/- MR C-/ US guided aspiration

clinical_scenario: Female with breast pain but no other suspicious clinical features or risk factors in history. Any age.
Female with clinically significant breast pain (focal and noncyclical) and lumpiness or other suspicious feature on exam and/or positive family history or other risk factor. Initial imaging.
Male patient any age with symptoms of gynecomastia and physical examination consistent with gynecomastia or pseudo-gynecomastia. No focal abnormality on exam
comment: Follow gynaecomastia pathway and plastics- referral criteria

clinical_scenario: Male any age with focal unilateral abnormality /indeterminate palpable breast mass. Initial imaging following breast specialist review

Male of any age with indeterminate palpable breast mass/ focal unilateral abnormality cancer (suspicious palpable breast mass, axillary adenopathy, nipple discharge, or nipple retraction). Initial imaging.
Clinically significant pain on the side of the mastectomy with or without reconstruction (autologous or non-autologous). Initial imaging.
comment: Any imaging done should be based on breast specialist review

clinical_scenario: Palpable lump on the side of the mastectomy with or without reconstruction (autologous or non-autologous). Initial imaging.
Palpable breast mass. Female, <40 years of age, initial evaluation.
comment: P3 unless >1mth duration or associated with another clinical/risk feature (e.g. If fixed, hard, FHx or palpable LNs) and then P2. (as per FCT criteria)

clinical_scenario: Palpable breast mass. Female, 40 years of age or older, initial evaluation.
Physiologic nipple discharge. Female of any age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Female younger than 30 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge. Male younger than 30 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Male or female 30 to 39 years of age. Initial imaging examination.
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). Male or female 40 years of age or older. Initial imaging examination.
Known breast cancer. Axillary evaluation prior to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Initial imaging examination.
Known breast cancer with clinical suspicion of metastatic disease. Staging or assessment of response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Initial imaging examination.
Palpable breast mass. Female, younger than 30 years of age, initial evaluation.
comment: Upgrade to P2 if clinically suspicious

clinical_scenario: Breast Multidisciplinary group recommends staging
modality: CT CAP + bone scan or CT PET

clinical_scenario: Surveillance. Personal history of breast cancer. Asymptomatic. Rule out local recurrence.
Clinical suspicion of inflammatory breast cancer
2nd look imaging for findings on MRI or CT
Further work up, biopsy or imaging recommended by the Breast Multidisciplinary meeting
Post operative seroma unable to be drained without imaging guidance
Follow up imaging recommended on previous breast imaging
Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably malignant or indeterminate lesion (including papilloma)
Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably benign lesion (suspected fibrocystic changes or fibroadenoma)
New diagnosis breast cancer with high background risk of undetected disease (e.g. BRCA-1; dense breasts) AND as recommended by MDM
Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS clear on mammogram and/or US
Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS NOT clear on mammogram or US and MR recommended by MDM
Non-calcified (typically high grade) DCIS to define extent for surgical planning and where recommended by MDM e.g. particularly with dense breasts
Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) where breast conserving surgery is being considered
Pre-and post- neoadjuvant chemotherapy, with a view to downstaging the lesion and allowing breast conserving surgery
Lumpectomy with a positive margin. If multiple positive margins, to move straight to mastectomy and nil MR
Fixed tumour, ?Invasion to deep fascia and neoadjuvant chemo or radiotherapy to establish a clear margin prior to surgery is being considered. Recommended by MDM
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). No cause identified on DBI and ongoing concerns

Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
modality: US +/- MR C-/ US guided aspiration

clinical_scenario: Positive axillary node, ?occult breast primary
Recurrence, ?Invasion to deep fascia
Complications of breast reconstruction (non-implant)
Silicone implant (non-cosmetic) complications where the US is equivocal
comment: Radiologist or clinician may indicate P3- non-deferrable

clinical_scenario: High risk screening (BRCAs etc.)
Follow-up MRI surveillance of women could be considered, where initial presentation with palpable mass (biopsy positive) was occult on mammogram and ultrasound, but visible on MRI.
Chest pain syndrome - not clear ACS/intermediate probability of CAD
Low probability coronary artery disease
New presentation cardiomyopathy
Previous CHF, currently stable
Suspected/new diagnosis of congenital heart disease
modality: XR ECHO MRI CTA IF CORO

clinical_scenario: Follow up congenital heart disease in the adult
Moderate or severe hypertension: diastolic pressure
High index of suspicion of renovascular hypertension and normal renal function
High index of suspicion of renovascular hypertension and diminished renal function
Cardiac valve surgery, non-urgent non-cardiac surgery
Urgent non-cardiac surgery e.g. cancer. Possible IHD
Cardiac tumour
Dilated aorta, prior dissection, prior aortic surgery or stent
Pericardial constriction / disease
New presentation cardiomyopathy
Non-ischaemic/Infiltration suspected
Ischaemic - viability
Ischaemia Stress perfusion
Chest pain clinic/CTO planning/graft patency
Chronic, intermittent, or low grade
Woman of childbearing age
comment: CT first unless pain suggests pelvic origin more likely

clinical_scenario: Obese patient
Palpable mass, high or moderate suspicion of cancer clinically
Palpable mass, low clinical suspicion for cancer or pulsatile and painless
Average-risk individual after positive faecal occult blood test (FOBT), indicating a relative elevation in risk
Average-risk, moderate-risk or high-risk individual after incomplete colonoscopy
Moderate-risk individual: personal history or adenoma or carcinoma or first-degree family history of cancer or adenoma
High-risk individual: hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)
Rectal cancer Staging
comment: Deferrable only while having pre-op chemo

clinical_scenario: Colon cancer (other than rectum)
Colorectal MDM review recommends PET-CT
comment: Deferrable only while having pre-op chemo

clinical_scenario: Mesenteric ischaemia, subacute to chronic
Constipation
prioritisation: P4 or P2 if red flags

clinical_scenario: Hypopituitarism
comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

clinical_scenario: Obesity/eating disorder
Hyperthyroidism (high TSH)
Cushing's syndrome (high ACTH)
Hyperprolactinemia
comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

clinical_scenario: Acromegaly/gigantism
comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

clinical_scenario: Growth hormone deficiency, growth deceleration, panhypopituitarism
comment: P1 if visual fields abnormal, P4 if normal

clinical_scenario: Diabetes insipidus
Postoperative sella
Precocious puberty

Palpable thyroid nodule, suspicious features (e.g. painless rapid growth over 2-3 months, history of voice change +/or stridor, youth/child, family history of MEN, neck nodes), euthyroid, initial imaging
Palpable thyroid nodule, no suspicious features for thyroid cancer, euthyroid, initial imaging
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH normal or elevated and >1.5cm if >35y and >1.0cm if <35y
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH reduced.
Incidental FDG-avid nodule on PET CT
Suspected goitre. Initial imaging. Obstructive symptoms
Thyrotoxicosis. Initial imaging
Primary hypothyroidism. Initial Imaging
Medullary thyroid cancer on biopsy
Thyroid cancer, surgery considered, anaplastic ca or metastatic disease suspected
No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter. Initial evaluation.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

clinical_scenario: No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter. Follow-up evaluation in 12 months.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

clinical_scenario: No history of malignancy; mass >4 cm in diameter. (If not typical for adenoma, myelolipoma, haemorrhage or simple cyst, consider resection). Clinical review pre-biopsy.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

clinical_scenario: History of malignancy; mass > 4 cm in diameter. Clinical review pre-biopsy.
Imaging recommended by MDM
Post op care/complications
Any aetiology; best initial study, (septic arthritis not-suspected clinically)
comment: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

clinical_scenario: X-ray non-contributory. Persistent significant pain. Physical examination and history nonspecific. Next study.
X-ray non-contributory. Age less than 35 years, suspect labral tear with or without instability on physical examination.
X-ray non-contributory. Questionable bursitis or long head of biceps tenosynovitis based on clinical findings including physical examination.
comment: ???? Normal x-ray or x-ray demonstrates coracoacromial arch osteophytes/syndesmophytes. Suspect rotator cuff tear/ impingement, over 35 years. US first investigation. If concern of complete tendon tear especially subscapularis and especially in younger patients, then P3 or less is better

clinical_scenario: X-ray non-contributory. Previous total shoulder arthroplasty. Suspect rotator cuff tear.
X-ray non-contributory. Status post prior rotator cuff repair. Suspect re-tear.
comment: P3. Earlier timeframe better for potential surgical repair. US first

clinical_scenario: ?arthritis ?other
modality: XR, then US if normal XR and cuff tear suspected

clinical_scenario: Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; ossicles on x-ray
Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; X-rays NAD
Suspect occult injury e.g. osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect unstable osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect mass; radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect chronic epicondylitis, radiographs nondiagnostic.
Suspect collateral ligament tear; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comment: In rare situation of grossly unstable elbow and considering acute ligament repair/reconstructive surgery then MRI within 2 days appropriate. Otherwise all ligament investigations by specialist only and category P 4 and deferrable

clinical_scenario: Suspect biceps tendon tear and/or bursitis; radiographs non-diagnostic.
comment: if distal biceps tear should be P2. U/S first if suspect complete tear. MRI for query partial tear or if diagnosis uncertain

clinical_scenario: Suspect nerve abnormality; radiographs nondiagnostic.
?arthritis ?other
comment: XR first- further imaging e.g. US, based on clinician review

clinical_scenario: Suspect acute distal radius fracture. Radiographs normal. Next procedure.
Comminuted, intra-articular distal radius fracture on radiographs. Surgical planning.
Suspect acute scaphoid fracture. X-rays normal. Next procedure.
Suspected occult scaphoid fracture. Initial and repeat x-rays after 10-14 days of casting normal. Continued clinical suspicion of scaphoid fracture. Next procedure.
comment: P2 i.e. patient already in cast

clinical_scenario: Suspect distal radioulnar joint subluxation.
Suspect hook of the hamate fracture. Initial radiographs normal or equivocal.
comment: CT first and then MRI if occult fracture still suspected

clinical_scenario: Suspect metacarpal fracture or dislocation.
Suspect gamekeeper injury (thumb MCP ulnar collateral ligament injury).
modality: XR then US if normal XR
comment: XR P1 if NAD, then US P2>P3

clinical_scenario: With or without prior injury. Best initial study.
Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Persistent symptoms. Next study.
Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Suspect arthritis ( other than septic). Next study.
Nonspecific arthritis on x-ray. Exclude infection. Next study.
Pain on ulnar side, suspect triangular fibrocartilage or lunotriquetral ligament tear. Radiographs normal. Next study.
X-rays show positive ulnar variance and irregularity in proximal lunate articular surfaces. Next study.
X-rays normal or equivocal. Suspect Kienbock's disease. Next study.
Kienbock's disease on x-rays. Next study.
Pain for more than 3 weeks. Suspect occult fracture. Radiographs nondiagnostic. Next study.
Suspect carpal tunnel syndrome.
modality: Usually none/ XR only if concern of contributory arthritis

clinical_scenario: Avascular necrosis is suspected clinically.
comment: MRI if XR normal or inconclusive

clinical_scenario: Avascular necrosis with femoral head collapse on x-ray of the painful hip
comment: MRI only if requested by subspecialty hip surgeon. Deferrable if no surgery contemplated.

clinical_scenario: Initial evaluation for chronic hip pain. First test.
Rapidly increasing hip pain, not typical for usual OA progression
comment: e.g. active inflammatory arthritis and rapid destruction and collapse of the femoral head

clinical_scenario: X-rays negative, suspect osseous or surrounding soft-tissue abnormality, excluding osteoid osteoma.
X-rays negative, suspect osteonecrosis. Includes circumstances in which hip is asymptomatic but osteonecrosis is suspected due to known predisposing factors.
X-rays negative. Suspect osteoid osteoma.
comment: MRI first and if negative consider CT and bone scan

clinical_scenario: X-rays negative, suspect labral tear with or without clinical findings consistent with or suggestive or femoro-acetabular impingement.
X-rays negative or mild osteoarthritis. Suspect referred pain but wish to exclude hip.
X-rays positive, arthritis uncertain type. Infection not a consideration.
Radiographs positive, suggestive of pigmented villo-nodular synovitis or osteochondromatosis.
Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate degenerative joint disease and/or chondrocalcinosis.

Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate inflammatory, crystalline, or degenerative joint disease (uni- to tri-compartmental sclerosis, hypertrophic spurs, joint space narrowing, and/or subchondral cysts).
Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate avascular necrosis.
Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee radiographs x-rays evidence of internal derangement (e.g. Segond fracture, deep lateral femoral notch sign).
Pain after TKA: initial evaluation.
Pain after TKA: positive aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA: positive x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA: negative x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Routine follow-up of asymptomatic patients with TKA.
Chronic ankle pain of any origin - best initial study.
Multiple sites of degenerative joint disease by ankle x-rays. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected osteochondral injury. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected tendon abnormality. Next study.
Acute presentation, flare, or surveillance
Screening, first study.
Persistent symptoms, but x-ray negative.
Definitively benign on x-rays (excluding osteoid osteoma).
comment: (unless risk of # and aggressive benign appearance and then P2)

clinical_scenario: Clinically suspected osteoid osteoma.
Suspicious for malignant characteristics on x-ray
Clinically suspected soft-tissue mass: general.
Mass palpated at a joint.
Soft-tissue mass: limb.
Soft-tissue mass: abdominal or chest wall.
comment: Often CT first to confirm lesion, then MRI for further characterisation

clinical_scenario: Calcified soft-tissue mass not definitely benign seen on x-rays.
Negative or nonspecific findings on x-rays in area of palpated mass.
Follow-up of spontaneous soft-tissue haemorrhage in older adults.
Lower-risk patient (low grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Higher-risk patient (high grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Evaluation for osseous metastatic disease from musculoskeletal primary.
Surveillance for local recurrence.
Osseous tumour Local recurrence.
Soft-tissue tumour. Local recurrence.
Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child).
Asymptomatic. Structural lesion on physical examination (cervical bruit) and/or risk factors.
comment: Asymptomatic carotid bruit not routinely imaged

clinical_scenario: Chronic epilepsy, poor therapeutic response. Surgery candidate.
New onset seizure. ETOH, and/or drug related.
New onset seizure. Aged 18 - 40 years.
New onset seizure. Older than age 40.
Single or multiple focal neurologic deficits.
Chronic headache. No new features.
Chronic headache with new features.
New headache in patients older than age 60. Sedimentation rate higher than 55, temporal tenderness. Suspected temporal arteritis.
comment: May be nil imaging if clinically confident of the diagnosis

clinical_scenario: Possible/probable Alzheimer's disease.
Suspected vascular dementia or rapidly progressive dementia or mixed vascular dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
Frontotemporal dementia.
Dementia with Lewy bodies.
Suspected prion disease (Creutzfeldt-Jakob, iatrogenic CJ, or variant CJ)
Suspected normal pressure hydrocephalus.
comment: Depends on clinical setting. In the subacute setting, CT may be helpful for immediate management, with MRI only if needed.

clinical_scenario: Suspected Huntington disease
Clinical features suggestive of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA).
Parkinson's disease: typical clinical features and responds to levodopa.
Parkinsonian syndrome: atypical clinical features not responsive to levodopa.
Motor neuron disease.
comment: P3, not deferrable (can be useful occasionally), given the nature of this condition should be done <6 weeks. Spine may be required also.

clinical_scenario: Routine 12-month follow up, on medication for MS
Follow up of MS with ?new relapse
Risk for unruptured aneurysm. Positive family history.
comment: MRA>CTA due to radiation and better to have same baselines for follow up

clinical_scenario: Proven SAH, negative angiogram, follow-up.
comment: Case by case, some should have repeat DSA in a week, others just MRA or longer interval

clinical_scenario: No neurological deficit
Routine follow up glioma/GBM
Follow up of glioma/GBM and considering treatment (e.g. is nodular enhancement enlarging)
Follow up of glioma/GBM with new/worsening symptoms
Routine follow up
Routine surveillance
Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. First study.
Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up.
comment: Follow up scan would be at referring clinicians discretion and time accordingly however would be non-deferable from the specified time.

clinical_scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding. First study.
comment: This is a large cohort of pts and individual consideration to cases is needed to determine time frame. If any high-risk clinical factors may need to be triaged P2.

clinical_scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up.
comment: Follow up scan post endometrial sampling or other management may not always be mandatory e.g. after removal of endo polyp. If high clinical risk, then triage 3 or even P2 if symptomatic anaemia.

clinical_scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up of multi-fibroid uterus as per clinician/ radiologist recommendation
comment: Relatively low risk , e.g. on clinical discretion a follow up of multi-fibroid uterus is required S4.

clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.
comment: If a suspected mass with pain or bleeding then P2, otherwise P3.

clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography; NOT clearly malignant. Follow-up recommendations.
comment: Can be planned triage as either 6 weeks or 3 months follow up ultrasound depending on clinician recommendation or MDM review.

clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography getting smaller at short-term follow-up. (If resolved, no further imaging necessary).
comment: Could defer to a 4 depending on symptoms, clinical risk and tumour markers. Clinician to indicate.

clinical_scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass that is persistent or enlarging on pelvic sonography at short-term follow-up.
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial sonography demonstrates a large and apparently simple cyst >6 cm in diameter.
comment: Could defer to a P4 depending on symptoms. Clinician to indicate.

clinical_scenario: Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea). Initial evaluation.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst >5 cm in diameter by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst 3-5 cm in diameter seen by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a complex or solid adnexal mass seen by pelvic sonography.
Pre-treatment of ovarian cancer or rule out recurrence
Invasive cancer of the cervix, FIGO stage 1b1 or greater
Endometrial cancer of the uterus
Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum -hCG positive
comment: If ectopic pregnancy suspected - same day imaging

clinical_scenario: Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum -hCG negative.
comment: Triage depends on clinical indication: acute versus chronic pain, associated bleeding. For example, acute pain ovarian torsion, haemorrhagic cyst etc will need triage P1. However, other pain non-specified could be triage P2. Clinician to indicate urgency.

clinical_scenario: Non Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum -hCG positive.
comment: Early pregnancy causes of pain not related to pregnancy i.e. UTI, appendicitis, ovarian, gallbladder.

clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester
comment: Scan to be tailored to location of pain i.e. Maternal adnexa, gallbladder, kidneys, appendix, placenta (abruption) etc. Assessment of foetal wellbeing is always required at a minimum as well unless pain is clearly renal or GB in origin.

clinical_scenario: 1st trimester, positive pregnancy test
comment: According to HealthPathways, urgency depends on clinical risk factors - if ectopic suspected or bleeding severe may need to be within 24 hours

clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms.
comment: Scan to determine cause of APH i.e. Placenta praevia, vasa praevia, placental abruption may need vaginal ultrasound. Growth assessment can be performed if due.

clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa diagnosed before 32 weeks.
comment: Any longer wait-time e.g. P2 should be at clinical discretion - including where already excluded vasa praevia on previous scan or already diagnosed placenta praevia or low-lying placenta at anatomy scan.

clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Uterine contractions, pain, > 20 weeks
2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Persistent low-lying placenta.
comment: Deferral to P2 at clinical discretion only

clinical_scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa, history of caesarean delivery.
comment: Need to exclude placenta accreta. May need transvaginal scan. If first scan triage P1. If placenta accreta already known from a previous scan, then can triage P2 or tailored/planned/32 weeks follow up based on clinician recommendation from previous MDM or other earlier discussions.

clinical_scenario: Risk of IUGR initial evaluation
comment: Risk of foetal demise if severe and poorly managed.

clinical_scenario: Small foetus, low or low normal fluid, follow-up studies
comment: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician..

clinical_scenario: Very small foetus, normal fluid, follow-up studies
comment: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferable.

clinical_scenario: Normal sized foetus, low or absent fluid, follow-up studies
comment: Follow up to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferrable.

clinical_scenario: Patient at risk for preterm delivery: 16-24 weeks gestation: cervical length 3cm on transvaginal ultrasound scan
comment: standard 2 week follow up screening scan for cervical length 16-24 weeks or as advised by PTB clinic

clinical_scenario: Patient at risk for preterm delivery (history of prior preterm birth or multiple gestations): 16-24 weeks gestation: cervix 3 cm long by transvaginal ultrasound scan
comment: May need a follow up scan sooner than standard 2-week interval at clinician discretion

clinical_scenario: 2nd or third trimester assessment of cervix after 24 weeks
comment: Assessment of cervical cerclage or monitoring of open cervix after 24 weeks gestation. Scan timing at clinician discretion depending on indication.

clinical_scenario: Adult presenting with a non-pulsatile solitary neck mass (afebrile).
Adult presenting with multiple neck masses.
Adult with a history of treatment for cancer presenting with a neck mass.
Uncomplicated rhinosinusitis.
Recurrent acute or chronic rhinosinusitis (possible surgical candidate).
Bilateral sino-nasal polyposis
Sino-nasal obstruction, suspected mass lesion.
Sensorineural hearing loss, acute and intermittent vertigo.
Sensorineural hearing loss, no vertigo.
Conductive hearing loss, to rule out petrous bone abnormality.
Total deafness, cochlear implant candidate, surgical planning.
Fluctuating hearing loss, history of meningitis or to rule out congenital anomaly.
Vertigo, no hearing loss, normal neurological examination.
Anosmia and abnormalities of the sense of smell.
Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of mastication; sensory abnormalities of the head and neck.
Weakness or paralysis of facial expression.
Palate weakness.
Vocal cord paralysis.
Weakness or paralysis of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
Weakness or paralysis of the tongue.
Perineural spread of tumour.
No response to non-operative treatment
Unexplained oropharyngeal dysphagia.
Oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause.
Neurocognitive regression
Developmental delay, cerebral palsy, spinal dysraphism
Macrocephaly-stable, in otherwise normal child
Progressive macrocephaly
Microcephaly
Focal/partial seizure
Seizures with regression or arrest in development
Generalised seizures, no neurology, even if intractable
Progressive headache without neurological signs or symptoms of raised ICP
Chronic headache with no neurological signs
Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child)
Multiple focal neurologic deficits
Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, stable, or incompletely resolving
Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, progressive
Single focal neurologic deficit, completely resolving
Hypopituitarism
comment: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal

clinical_scenario: Obesity/eating disorder LOW 4
Hyperthyroidism (high TSH)
Cushing's syndrome (high ACTH)
Hyperprolactinemia
comment: P1 if abnormal visual fields or prolactin otherwise P3

clinical_scenario: Acromegaly/gigantism
Variant 7 - Growth hormone deficiency, growth deceleration, panhypopituitarism
comment: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal

clinical_scenario: Diabetes insipidus
Pituitary apoplexy
Postoperative sella
Precocious puberty
Child (up to age 14) presenting with a solitary neck mass or multiple neck masses (afebrile)
Children with uncomplicated acute sinusitis
Children with persistent (acute sinusitis that does not respond to treatment), recurrent, or chronic sinusitis
Children with sinusitis with orbital or intracranial complications
DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, hip instability or dislocation detected or suspected on exam.
DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, breech presentation or positive family history, stable hips on exam
DDH - Patient 4 months of age or older, clinically suspicious for DDH (limited abduction or abnormal gait)
Limp - Non-focal clinical examination
Limp - Focal clinical examination (not septic arthritis)
Cystic Fibrosis
comment: Annual + prn CXR. US for portal hypertension age 5 then annual or prn. HRCT age 6.

clinical_scenario: Bronchiectasis
IBD work up
IBD extension of disease or symptomatic
IBD perianal region
IBD collection or phlegmon suspected
Intermittent nonbilious vomiting since birth.
New onset projectile nonbilious vomiting.
UTI
Antenatal renal dilatation
Post treatment
Uncomplicated UTI, age <6 months, first episode
Recurrent infections (>/=2 episodes of culture positive UTI or high suspicion previous episode/s missed)
Gross, painless haematuria and no evident cause
Persistent, isolated microscopic haematuria on urine microscopy (>1 year) without proteinuria and increased urinary calcium or calcium creatinine ratio
Dipstick positive proteinuria and confirmed on PCR on early morning sample, when child is well
Enuresis - secondary
CXR pneumonia follow up.
comment: P3 if CXR showed mass like pneumonia, looked like pneumonia but with no signs of infection, or looked like a pneumonia with pleural fluid. P4 if standard typical pneumonia (AV)

clinical_scenario: Any age, positive physical examination.
Older than age 40, negative physical examination.
Younger than age 40, negative physical exam. Positive with other symptoms, severe dyspnoea, or other risk factors.
Younger than age 40, negative physical examination.
Any age, non-revealing or non-diagnostic clinical, standard radiography, and laboratory studies.
comment: Duration and severity dependant. P3 if symptoms <2 months or >2months if progressive. P4 if >2 months

clinical_scenario: Suspected ILD
Suspected bronchiectasis
Persistent/recurrent haemoptysis >40 years old +/- smoking history
comment: P2 CXR first then P3 CT if CXR normal

clinical_scenario: Adult - any age
comment: routine CXR only if surgical emphysema or asymmetrical signs

clinical_scenario: Nodule  1 cm and </= 3cms, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
comment: P3 if no previous imaging P4 if stable

clinical_scenario: Nodule  1 cm and </= 3cms, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.
comment: Consider direct referral for CT PET if resectable on CXR

clinical_scenario: Nodule  1 cm, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
Nodule  1 cm, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.
Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest curative
Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest non-curative
Asymptomatic; history and physical unremarkable.
Acute cardiopulmonary findings by history or physical.
Chronic cardiopulmonary disease in the elderly (age >70), previous chest radiograph within 6 months available.

Clinical differential insufficiency fracture versus metastasis in sacrum. X-rays normal, bone scan hot but nonspecific.

Suspect sub-acute insufficiency fracture of hip in osteoporotic patient or patient on corticosteroid therapy. X-rays normal.
